qas.question: What is the name of the Buddhist doctrine that states that phenomena arise together in a mutually interdependent web of cause and effect?

answers.text: pratītyasamutpāda, (Sanskrit; Pali: paticcasamuppāda; Tibetan Wylie: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba; Chinese: 緣起)

qas.question: Translated into English, what does pratītyasamutpāda mean?

answers.text: "dependent origination", "conditioned genesis", "dependent relationship", "dependent co-arising", "interdependent arising", or "contingency"

qas.question: The doctrine of pratityasumatupada is a important part of what type of metaphysics?

context: The doctrine of <a0_0>pratītyasamutpāda, (Sanskrit; Pali: paticcasamuppāda; Tibetan Wylie: rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba; Chinese: 緣起)<a0_0/> is an important part of <a2_0>Buddhist<a2_0/> metaphysics. It states that phenomena arise together in a mutually interdependent web of cause and effect. It is variously rendered into English as <a1_0>"dependent origination", "conditioned genesis", "dependent relationship", "dependent co-arising", "interdependent arising", or "contingency"<a1_0/>.
